item.title: Disease
item.description: Reading Anderson, R. M. and May, R. M., Population biology of infectious diseases I Nature 280 (5721), 361 (1979). pdf available here Kilpatrick, A. M. & Altizer, S. (2010) Disease Ecology. Nature Education Knowledge 3(10):55 link to paper

item.title: Introduction
item.description: Introductions Go around and introduce yourselves, what year you are, and what made you decide to take the course (could take many forms, including what you want to learn, what you’re interested in, etc. etc.) Syllabus Go over syllabus What are we doing in this class? Theory provides us a lens to generalize. Theory provides us a way to predict. Theory provides link between lab systems and natural systems. What this course is not A programming course.

item.title: Life history
item.description: Reading Chapter 7. Illustrated Guide to Theoretical Ecology.

item.title: Macroecology
item.description: Reading Brian J McGill. 2018. The what, how and why of doing macroecology. Global Ecology and Biogeography. pdf available here Brian McGill and Cathy Collins. 2003. A unified theory for macroecology based on spatial patterns of abundance. Evolutionary Ecology Research. pdf available here

item.title: metapopulations
item.description: Reading Chapter 16. Illustrated Guide to Theoretical Ecology.

item.title: Multi-species communities
item.description: Reading Chapter 15. Illustrated Guide to Theoretical Ecology.

item.title: Population growth
item.description: Reading Chapters 1 & 2. Illustrated Guide to Theoretical Ecology. From chapter 2, we will focus on individual variation and temporal variation instead of the spatial bits. Still worth reading the first part of chapter 2 on spatial variation, but for simplicity (and to not introduce space yet) we will go into more detail on pages 30 - 43 of chapter 2.

item.description: Reading Chapters 10 & 11. Illustrated Guide to Theoretical Ecology.

item.description: Reading Chapter 9. Illustrated Guide to Theoretical Ecology.
